questions.text: Which structure forms the lateral wall of the anterior horn of the lateral ventricle?
questions.correct_answer: B. Head of the caudate nucleus
questions.explanation:
Relations of Lateral Ventricles

Corpus Callosum

(Option A ruled out)

Caudate Nucleus

(Option B)
  • Roof of the body of lateral ventricle
  • Roof, floor and Anterior Wall of the Frontal horn
  • Roof, medial and lateral wall of Occipital horn
  • Lateral part of the Roof of the Temporal Horn
  • Head - Lateral wall and floor of Anterior Horn
  • Body - Part of the Floor of the body of the Lateral ventricle
  • Tail - Roof of inferior/temporal horn

questions.text: Which cranial nerve sensory fibres transmit sensory information from the skin and mucous membranes of the face, head, and neck?

A 7-year-old girl presents with severe headaches, vomiting, and papilloedema. Imaging reveals obstructive hydrocephalus due to a tumour blocking the exit of cerebrospinal fluid from the fourth ventricle. Which of the following structures is most likely blocked?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Foramen of Magendie

(Median aperture)

Foramina of Luschka

(Lateral aperture)

Location

Caudal to the cerebellar nodule

At the ends of the lateral recesses of the 4th ventricle.

Function

Main communication between ventricles and subarachnoid space

Allow communication between the fourth ventricle and the subarachnoid space.

Associated Pathology

Obstruction leads to hydrocephalus.

 

A blockage here would prevent CSF from exiting medially into the subarachnoid space.

Obstruction leads to hydrocephalus.

 

A blockage here prevents CSF from exiting laterally from the fourth ventricle.

Symptoms of Obstruction

Headache, vomiting, papilloedema

Headache, vomiting, papilloedema

questions.text: Which of the given options are correctly matched based on the image given?
What is a primary characteristic of Benign External Hydrocephalus (BEH) in infants?
questions.explanation:
Benign External Hydrocephalus

Definition

Increase in subarachnoid space volume with minimal ventricular enlargement, leading to macrocephaly (large head).

Causes
  • Impaired CSF absorption because of arachnoid villi immaturity
  • Venous defects

Clinical features
  • Increased head circumference- raised ICP
  • Poor motor development
  • Hypotonia, vomiting and seizures.

Investigations
  • Through CT or MRI imaging showing subarachnoid space widening;
  • Clinical assessment.

Treatment
  • Conservative Observation: For cases without significant symptoms.
  • Surgical Options: Considered if increased ICP or other complications are present (e.g., ventriculoperitoneal shunt).

questions.text: Match the following wall of the 3rd ventricle with its respective component. 1. Anterior wall a) Hypothalamus 2. Posterior Wall b) Mammillary bodies 3. Lateral wall c) Lamina terminalis 4. Floor d) Pineal gland
questions.explanation:
Wall of 3rd Ventricle

Components

Anterior Wall
  • Anterior column of fornix
  • Anterior commissure
  • Lamina terminalis

Posterior Wall
  • Pineal gland
  • Posterior commissure
  • Commencement of cerebral aqueduct

Roof

Formed by the ependyma that stretches across the upper limits of two thalami

Floor
  • Optic chiasma
  • Tuber cinereum and infundibulum
  • Mammillary bodies
  • Posterior perforated substance
  • Tegmentum of the midbrain

Lateral Walls
  • Divided by Hypothalamic sulcus into:
    • Large superior part- Medial surface of the thalamus.
    • Small inferior part- Hypothalamus and it is continuous with the ventricular floor.

questions.text: Match the following boundary of the 4th ventricle with its component. 1. Lateral wall a) Superior medullary velum 2. Posterior wall b) Superior medulla 3. Rhomboid fossa c) Superior cerebellar peduncle
questions.explanation:
Boundaries of 4th Ventricle

Description

Lateral Wall
  • Inferolaterally- Inferior cerebellar peduncle, and gracile and cuneate tubercles
  • Superolaterally- Superior cerebellar peduncle

Roof (Posterior Wall)
  • Superior Part:
    • Medial borders of the two superior cerebellar peduncles.
    • Superior medullary velum (a sheet of white matter).
  • Inferior Part:
    • Inferior medullary velum (ventricular ependyma and pia mater)
    • Median aperture (foramen of Magendie) in the midline.
  • Lateral Recesses:
    • Extend laterally around the medulla.
    • Open anteriorly as the foramina of Luschka (lateral openings of the fourth ventricle).

Rhomboid Fossa (Floor)
  • The posterior surface of the pons
  • The upper part of the medulla

questions.text: Which structure in the floor of the 4th ventricle consists of transverse white fibres derived from the arcuate nuclei?
Which of the following does not cross the midline?
questions.explanation:
Commissural fibres

Projection

They connect one hemisphere to the opposite side, linking corresponding (homotopic) or different (heterotopic) areas. 

  • Corpus Callosum: The largest commissural structure connecting the two cerebral hemispheres, located at the bottom of the longitudinal fissure. (Option A ruled out)
  • Anterior Commissure: A smaller bundle of nerve fibres crossing the midline at the lamina terminalis.(Option B ruled out)
  • Fornix: Composed of myelinated fibres, it connects the hippocampus to the mammillary bodies in the hypothalamus. It connects the hippocampal formations of the 2 sides. (Option C ruled out)

Projection fibres connect the cerebral cortex with subcortical structures, including the brainstem and spinal cord, and include both descending (corticofugal) and ascending (corticopetal) fibres.

These fibres converge in the corona radiata, pass through the internal capsule, and are flanked by the caudate nucleus and thalamus medially, and the lentiform nucleus laterally.

questions.text: Which association fibre connects Wernicke's area with Broca's area
questions.explanation:
Arcuate fasciculus

Uncinate fasciculus

(Option A ruled out)

Inferior and Superior longitudinal fasciculus

(Option B & D ruled out)
  • It is seen on the left side of the cerebrum.
  • In 95% of people, the language area is on the left dominant hemisphere.
  • Wernicke's sensory speech area in the temporal lobe is connected with Broca's motor speech area in the inferior frontal gyrus by arcuate fasciculus.
  • It does not cross the midline.
  • Connecting the temporal lobe with the frontal lobe.
  • It does not cross the midline.
  • Superior longitudinal fasciculus: Connects the anterior part of the frontal lobe to the occipital and temporal lobes.
  • Inferior longitudinal fasciculus: Connects the occipital lobe to the temporal lobe.
  • They do not cross the midline.

questions.text: Which part of the corpus callosum contains fibres that connect the right and left occipital cortices?
Which cranial nerve motor fibres are responsible for innervating skeletal muscles that develop from somites?
questions.explanation:
Motor Neural Columns
 

GSE (General Somatic Efferent)

(Option A)

GVE (General Visceral Efferent)

(Option C ruled out)

SVE (Special Visceral Efferent )

(Option B ruled out)

Innervation

Motor innervation to skeletal muscles that develop from somites.

Autonomic (involuntary) innervation to smooth muscles and glands.

Innervate muscles that are derived from pharyngeal arches, not somites.

Function

Voluntary movements such as eye and tongue movements.

Functions such as pupil constriction, salivation, digestion, and heart rate regulation.

Functions like facial expression, mastication, and swallowing.

Nerves
  • Oculomotor (III)
  • Trochlear (IV)
  • Abducens (VI)
  • Hypoglossal (XII)
  • Oculomotor (III)
  • Facial (VII)
  • Glossopharyngeal (IX)
  • Vagus (X)
  • Facial (VII)
  • Trigeminal (V)
  • Accessory spinal nerve (XI)

questions.text: Which cranial nerve sensory fibres are primarily responsible for transmitting sensations from the tongue to the brainstem?
questions.explanation:
Special Sensory Column

Special Visceral Afferent (SVA) fibres

(Option B)

Special Somatic Afferent (SSA) fibres

(Option A ruled out)
  • SVA fibres are sensory fibres responsible for transmitting taste sensations from the tongue to the brainstem.
  • These fibres terminate in the nucleus solitarius in the medulla
  • Cranial nerves - Facial (VII), Glossopharyngeal (IX).
  • SSA fibres are responsible for transmitting sensory information related to the special senses of smell, vision, hearing, and balance.
  • The optic nerve (II), olfactory nerve (III), vestibulocochlear nerve (VIII) are part of SSA.

questions.text: What is the primary function of the alar plate in the developing neural tube?
Which of the following cranial nerve nuclei originates from the General Visceral Efferent (GVE) column of the basal plate?

A 5 year old boy came with complaints of sudden onset weakness in his lower limbs. His parents mention a history of viral illness with fever and sore throat. On examination, the boy has flaccid paralysis of his legs with muscle wasting, absent deep tendon reflexes, and no sensory deficits. Which of the following structures is primarily affected in this condition, leading to muscle paralysis and wasting?

options.label: A
options.text: Posterior white columns of the spinal cord

options.label: B
options.text: Anterior grey columns of the spinal cord

questions.correct_answer: B. Anterior grey columns of the spinal cord
